AP Computer Science A

Array-1

We will use what you've learned about arrays and for loops to solve some logic puzzles:

  1. Go to http://codingbat.com/java
  2. Do the coding problems in Array-1. All 27 problems in Array-1 must be done by Tuesday, September 9th.

Logic-1

We will use what you've learned about methods and if statements to solve some logic puzzles:

  1. Go to http://codingbat.com/java
  2. Click on "create account" and create an account. Make sure to put your name (last, first). This is not optional.
  3. After you have created your account, click on "prefs".
  4. In the "Share To" text box, enter my email address (tand@galileoweb.org). Click Share.
  5. Do the coding problems in Logic-1. All 30 problems in Logic-1 must be done by Thursday, September 4th.

Functions and Methods

Part 1:

We’re going to take another look at functions and do some math today. Complete this worksheet before moving on to Part 2.

Part 2:

We will now take our multi-variable functions and turn them into multi-parameter methods in Java. You will create two files in your Java project: GeometryLab.java and GeometryLabTest.java. The first Java file will have your method definitions from the worksheet. The second file will have a main method with the method invocations/calls from the worksheet and use System.out.println to print out your answers. Check your answers with the worksheet answers from Part 1.

CalendarPrinter

This program will be called CalendarPrinter for reasons that will shortly become obvious.  Start a new project CalendarPrinter and add a new Java class file CalendarPrinter with the usual main method. Call Mr. Tan over to check your program output and organization when you are finished.

When executed, your program should output:

September 1 – NO SCHOOL (LABOR DAY)
September 2
September 3
September 4
September 5
September 6 - WEEKEND
September 7 – WEEKEND
September 8
September 9
September 10
September 11
September 12
September 13 – WEEKEND
September 14 – WEEKEND
September 15
September 16
September 17
September 18
September 19
September 20 – WEEKEND
September 21 – WEEKEND
September 22
September 23
September 24
September 25
September 26 - END OF THE MARKING PERIOD
September 27 – WEEKEND
September 28 – WEEKEND
September 29
September 30

Your output should match the above exactly. Observe all capitalization, punctuation, and spacing. As you might expect, there are some other requirements for writing this program. The most important of these is that you may only have one line of code that calls System.out.println (and no uses of System.out.print). Clearly, there is more than one line of printed output. Therefore, you must use a loop and you must use conditionals (if statements) in your program. You must also have at least one String variable.

Welcome to AP Computer Science A!

Welcome to AP Computer Science A!

Here are the rules for Classcraft for you to look over: ClasscraftRules

Please complete the following two tasks today:

  • Fill out the Tech Survey. I will use this information to setup your Piazza and Classcraft accounts so do this first.
    • Tech Survey link
  • Write your first Hello World program in Java.
    1. Open Start Menu > All Programs > Programming tools > Eclipse
    2. Eclipse will ask you for a workspace. Choose a folder that you have access to (you may want to create one).
    3. Close the Welcome tab if it is displayed.
    4. Create a new Java Project by selecting File > New > Java Project
    5. Name your project "Hello" and click Finish.
    6. Create a new Java file by selecting File > New > Class
    7. Name your file "Hello". Make sure that the "public static void main(String[] args)" checkbox is checked. Click Finish.
    8. Within the curly braces of the main method, add the following line:
      System.out.println("Hello world");
    9. Compile and run your program by selecting Run > Run As > Java Application
    10. Check that "Hello world" appears in the Eclipse console.

Again, welcome to APCSA! Let's have a fun and exciting year!
